The trust and participation agreements may be modified or amended on a retroactive basis in order to maintain compliance with 26 U.S.C. (Internal Revenue Code) and to maintain efficient operation of the trust as determined by the board.
A name, address, or other information identifying a person as a participant or beneficiary in the trust is confidential.
In this section,
account means an individual trust account established under this section;
beneficiary means a designated beneficiary as defined under 26 U.S.C. 529(e);
board means the Board of Regents of the University of Alaska;
member of the family has the meaning given in 26 U.S.C. 529(e);
participant means a person who has entered into a participation agreement or has been appointed as a participant as provided in this section and in the participation agreement;

participation agreement means an agreement between a participant and the board providing for the establishment by the participant of one or more accounts under this section and for the administration of those accounts for the benefit of the participant and the beneficiary;
qualified education expenses has the meaning given to qualified higher education expenses in 26 U.S.C. 529(c) and (e);
trust means the Education Trust of Alaska.

section.heading: Alaska advance college tuition savings fund.

content.p: The Alaska advance college tuition savings fund is established as a nonlapsing fund of the University of Alaska. The purpose of the fund is to secure obligations to participants under a postsecondary education savings program operated by the University of Alaska and to enhance the ability of the university to provide (1) higher education for the people of the state; (2) wide and affordable access to higher education for residents and their children; (3) an incentive for residents to achieve higher academic standards in grades 7  12; and (4) an incentive for residents to continue and complete secondary and postsecondary education. The fund may be divided into separate accounts for accounting purposes.
The fund consists of
appropriations, gifts, bequests, and contributions; and
income and earnings of the fund.

Assets of the fund shall be expended to make payments to the university and other eligible educational institutions, including payments for refunds, redemptions, and awards under a savings contract or scholarships, costs of administration, and other obligations of the fund.

section.heading: Contribution to the Alaska Advance College Tuition Savings Fund.

content.p: Contributions to the fund under the terms of an advance college tuition savings contract may be made by direct cash payments or by contributions from the permanent fund dividend. The Department of Revenue shall

prepare the permanent fund dividend application to allow an applicant or a parent, legal guardian, or other authorized representative of an applicant who is an unemancipated minor to contribute 50 percent of a dividend to the fund; and

include with each application for a permanent fund dividend an explanation of the advance college tuition savings program, including the right to receive a refund, a disclosure of the potential tax liability of the fund, and disclosure of the possible general effect of the tax liability on the advance college tuition savings program.
The Department of Revenue shall pay contributions directly to the fund.

In order to assure the actuarial soundness of the fund, the legislature may appropriate annually to the fund the sum, certified by the board to the governor and the legislature, that is necessary to restore the fund to an amount that is actuarially sound. The board annually, before January 30, shall make and deliver to the governor and to the legislature a certificate stating the sum required to restore the fund to an amount that is actuarially sound, and that sum may be appropriated and paid to the fund during that fiscal year. This subsection does not create a debt or liability of the state.

section.heading: Powers and duties of the University of Alaska.

content.p: The Board of Regents of the University of Alaska may contract with a purchaser for the purchase of advance college tuition credits for the payment of tuition and other qualified higher education expenses for a beneficiary of any age to attend a branch of the university or other eligible educational institution to which the beneficiary is admitted. A purchaser and a beneficiary may be the same person.
The board shall
make appropriate arrangements as necessary to fulfill the board's obligations under an advance college tuition savings contract;

establish and adopt a formal plan for administration of the advance college tuition savings program; the terms and conditions of the plan shall be considered a part of an advance college tuition savings contract;

establish investment objectives, criteria, and asset allocation guidelines for the fund based on prudent institutional investor guidelines and actuarial analysis of the earnings requirements for the advance college tuition savings plan;
enter into contracts or agreements considered necessary for the investment of the fund, including contracts or agreements with investment managers, consultants, and other custodians of the fund;
engage a financial advisor to report annually on the investment performance of the fund;
engage an independent firm of certified public accountants to audit the financial position of the fund;
do all acts, whether or not expressly authorized, that the board considers necessary or proper in administering the assets of the fund;

enter into reciprocal agreements with Alaska Pacific University and other eligible educational institutions or state tuition programs that the board determines to be beneficial to the advance college tuition savings program;
An advance college tuition savings contract must set out or include by reference to the plan
the name and date of birth of the purchaser and the beneficiary under the contract;
the number of advance college tuition credits purchased under the contract;
the terms and conditions under which the contract may be terminated and refunds made;
the assumption of a contractual obligation by the board to provide funding for specified education benefits for the beneficiary in accordance with the terms of the plan;
the period of time during which the beneficiary may receive the benefits of the contract; and
other terms and conditions the board determines to be appropriate or that are required under 26 U.S.C. (Internal Revenue Code).
An advance college tuition savings contract may be terminated
if the board determines that the number of purchasers is insufficient to maintain the fund on an actuarially sound basis; or
under other circumstances determined by the board and set out in the advance tuition savings contract or in the plan.
